data.text:
Anonymous asked:

Can you tell us about jumping spider body language? üï∑ They are so neat!

of course! this one‚Äôs a little tricky since there‚Äôs not much info specifically on their body language so i‚Äôm mostly going on what i‚Äôve personally seen.

curiousity: a jumper engaged in its surroundings will turn itself around and look up to investigate, tilt its body/head to one side, turn towards moving objects and gently lift its legs up and down as if pawing at the air. when investigating a human, jumpers ‚Äúflicker‚Äù their chelicerae (the colourful part of their fangs) and will even make direct eye contact, tilting their head back to do so. not sure why they do it, but they may also wave their legs ‚Äúat‚Äù you as if reaching for you.

content: a relaxed jumper doesn‚Äôt feel the need to run away, so it will sit quite comfortably with its legs tucked so that the frontmost ones are almost touching. my spiders do this pretty often when they‚Äôre hanging out with me outside their enclosures, especially when they‚Äôre sunbathing - one of the ladies i used to have got the name sunny because she would always walk into a patch of sunlight and sit in this position. relaxed jumpers may even clean themselves in your presence, one of the most famous examples seen in this video of a keeper petting their spider.

courting: when a mature male spots a female he will carefully approach her but keep his distance. once she sees him he rapidly lifts his front legs in the air and repeatedly ‚Äúflexes‚Äù them (as pepper does in his videos) while moving from side to side or in a zig-zag pattern towards her. this can look similar to a threat display, so watch for the fangs and the repetitive arm movements - the male‚Äôs fangs won‚Äôt be outstretched as if ready to bite. for inexperienced males this is trickier and they may come across more threatening than alluring.

aggression: can be seen when a male meets a rival male, or a male advances on a female who isn‚Äôt interested and has had enough. the aggressor will approach the other spider rapidly while posturing with the front legs raised up, abdomen raised off the ground and fangs clearly separated and extended as if ready to bite. it can look as though the spider wants to ‚Äúhug‚Äù the other, but once it gets close it may ram in to it and try to push it away.

defensive/cautious: usually when faced by another jumper and doesn‚Äôt want conflict, the spider will slowly back away and keep the legs tucked close to the body while watching the other spider intently. it will keep facing the other spider so as not to be caught off guard and will back further away if approached. in regard to humans, a defensive jumper who spots a human watching them will back away quickly, or if feeling particularly provoked, may even lunge at them as a warning to stay away.
